Plastic is a widely used material because it is versatile, lightweight, and inexpensive to produce. It is also durable and can be used for a wide range of applications, from packaging to construction, electronics, and more.

However, the downside of plastic is that it is not biodegradable, which means that it remains in the environment for hundreds of years, causing harm to wildlife, ecosystems, and even human health. Additionally, plastic often ends up in oceans and can break down into tiny particles known as microplastics, which are ingested by marine animals and can ultimately end up in the human food chain.

While there are efforts to reduce plastic usage, it is still a significant part of our daily lives, and finding alternatives that are just as effective and affordable has proven challenging. The key is to promote a circular economy, where plastics are recycled, reused or repurposed, keeping them in the economy and out of the environment.
